questions.text: In developing countries, healthcare facilities face various challenges in managing medical waste. Among the total healthcare wastes generated, a specific portion is classified as infectious, posing significant risks if not properly handled. As a healthcare administrator, you are preparing a report on waste management of your Hospital. Based on global health statistics, approximately what percentage of total healthcare waste in developing countries is classified as infectious waste?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 1.5%

Explanation:

  • • The average composition of health-care/ hospital wastes is as follows.
  • • average
  • • health-care/ hospital wastes
  • • Paper: 15% Plastic: 10% Rags: 15% Metals (Sharps, etc): 1.0% Infectious waste: 1.5% Glass: 4.0% General waste (food waste, sweeping of premises) : 53.5%
  • • Paper: 15%
  • • Paper: 15%
  • • Plastic: 10%
  • • Rags: 15%
  • • Rags: 15%
  • • Metals (Sharps, etc): 1.0%
  • • Infectious waste: 1.5%
  • • Infectious waste: 1.5%
  • • Glass: 4.0%
  • • General waste (food waste, sweeping of premises) : 53.5%
  • • General waste (food waste, sweeping of premises) : 53.5%
  • • Infectious waste : Contains pathogens ( bacteria, viruses, parasites, or fungi ) in sufficient concentration or quantity to cause disease in susceptible hosts . Includes Cultures , Waste from surgery and autopsies on patients with infectious diseases , Waste from infected patients in isolation wards (e.g. excreta, dressings ), Waste that has been in contact with infected patients undergoing haemodialysis, Infected animals from laboratories , Any other instruments or materials that have been in contact with infected persons or animals.
  • • Infectious waste
  • • bacteria, viruses, parasites, or fungi
  • • concentration or quantity
  • • susceptible hosts
  • • Cultures
  • • Waste
  • • surgery
  • • autopsies
  • • infectious diseases
  • • Waste
  • • infected patients
  • • isolation wards
  • • excreta, dressings
  • • Waste
  • • contact
  • • infected patients
  • • haemodialysis, Infected animals
  • • laboratories
  • • instruments or materials
  • • contact
  • • infected persons
  • • animals.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • The amount of infectious waste among hospital waste is 1.5%
  • • infectious waste
  • • hospital waste
  • • 1.5%
  • • Reference: Park 26 th ed pg. 883

questions.text: In India, glass products accounts for about __________ of the hospital waste?

A public health official is evaluating the disposal methods of healthcare waste at a regional hospital. One method under consideration is incineration, which can be effective for various waste types. However, certain characteristics of waste can make it less suitable for this process. Considering the properties of waste ideal for incineration, which of the following characteristics would make waste less suitable for incineration?

options.label: A
options.text: Content of combustible matter above 60 percent.

options.label: B
options.text: Content of non-combustible solids below 5 percent

options.label: D
options.text: Content of non-combustible fines below 20 percent

questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Moisture content above 20 percent

Explanation:

  • • Characteristics of the waste suitable for incineration are:
  • • Characteristics of the waste suitable for incineration are:
  • • Low heating volume – above 2,000 kcal/kg for single-chamber incinerators, and above 3,500 kcal/kg for pyrolytic double-chamber incinerators . Content of combustible matter above 60 percent . Content of non-combustible solids below 5 percent . Content of non-combustible fines below 20 percent ; and Moisture content below 30 percent
  • • Low heating volume – above 2,000 kcal/kg for single-chamber incinerators, and above 3,500 kcal/kg for pyrolytic double-chamber incinerators .
  • • Low heating volume
  • • 2,000 kcal/kg
  • • single-chamber
  • • incinerators,
  • • 3,500 kcal/kg
  • • pyrolytic double-chamber incinerators
  • • Content of combustible matter above 60 percent .
  • • combustible
  • • 60 percent
  • • Content of non-combustible solids below 5 percent .
  • • non-combustible solids
  • • 5 percent
  • • Content of non-combustible fines below 20 percent ; and
  • • non-combustible fines
  • • 20 percent
  • • Moisture content below 30 percent
  • • Moisture content below 30 percent
  • • Incineration
  • • Incineration
  • • It is a high-temperature dry oxidation process ; It leads to a significant reduction in waste volume and weight (up to 70-80% ).
  • • high-temperature dry oxidation process
  • • reduction
  • • waste volume
  • • weight
  • • 70-80%
  • • Incineration does not require pretreatment . The biggest disadvantage of incineration is the smoke generation.
  • • does not
  • • pretreatment
  • • disadvantage
  • • smoke generation.
  • • Types of Incinerators: Double chamber pyrolytic ; Single chamber pyrolytic; Rotary kilns
  • • Types
  • • Double chamber pyrolytic
  • • Single chamber
  • • pyrolytic; Rotary kilns
  • • Temperature in an incinerator (Now, > 1200°C recommended)
  • • Temperature
  • • > 1200°C
  • • Wastes types not to be incinerated are -
  • • Wastes types not to be incinerated are -
  • • Pressurized gas containers Reactive chemical wastes Silver/ Radiographic/ Photographic wastes Halogenated plastics (PVC) Wastes with high mercury/ cadmium content Sealed ampoules with heavy metals.
  • • Pressurized gas containers
  • • gas containers
  • • Reactive chemical wastes
  • • chemical
  • • Silver/ Radiographic/ Photographic wastes
  • • Silver/ Radiographic/ Photographic
  • • Halogenated plastics (PVC)
  • • Halogenated plastics
  • • Wastes with high mercury/ cadmium content
  • • high mercury/ cadmium content
  • • Sealed ampoules with heavy metals.
  • • Sealed
  • • ampoules
  • • heavy metals.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Incineration is a common method for disposing of healthcare waste , particularly effective for materials that can be easily burned . The suitability of waste for incineration depends on several factors , including its calorific value , combustibility, and moisture content.
  • ➤ Incineration
  • ➤ disposing
  • ➤ healthcare waste
  • ➤ effective
  • ➤ materials
  • ➤ easily burned
  • ➤ waste
  • ➤ incineration
  • ➤ several factors

questions.text: A local healthcare facility is looking to update its waste management system. They are considering adopting the screw feed technology for disposal of infectious waste. What is the primary result of utilizing screw feed technology in this context?

options.label: A
options.text: 85% reduction of volume and 15% reduction in weight.

options.label: B
options.text: 80% reduction in volume and 35% reduction in weight.

options.label: C
options.text: 75% reduction in volume and 45% reduction in weight.

options.label: D
options.text: 70% reduction in volume and 70% reduction in weight.

questions.correct_answer: B. 80% reduction in volume and 35% reduction in weight.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 80% reduction in volume and 35% reduction in weight.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation -
  • • SCREW FEED TECHNOLOGY
  • • SCREW FEED TECHNOLOGY
  • • Non-burn dry thermal disinfection process in which waste is shredded and then heated in a rotating auger .
  • • Non-burn dry thermal disinfection
  • • waste
  • • shredded
  • • heated
  • • rotating auger
  • • The waste is reduced by 80 percent in volume and by 20—35 percent in weight .
  • • waste
  • • reduced
  • • 80 percent
  • • volume
  • • 20—35 percent
  • • weight
  • • This process is suitable for treating infectious waste and sharps , but it should not be used to Process pathological , cytotoxic , or radio-active waste.
  • • treating infectious waste
  • • sharps
  • • not
  • • pathological
  • • cytotoxic
  • • radio-active waste.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Screw feed technology , a non-burn method , reducing volume by 80% and weight by 20-35%, is suitable for infectious & sharp waste but not for pathological, cytotoxic or radioactive waste.
  • ➤ Screw feed technology
  • ➤ non-burn method
  • ➤ reducing
  • ➤ volume
  • ➤ 80%
  • ➤ weight
  • ➤ 20-35%,
  • ➤ infectious & sharp waste
  • ➤ not
  • ➤ pathological, cytotoxic
  • ➤ radioactive waste.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Park 26 th ed pg. 885

questions.text: A hospital administrator is exploring methods to safely dispose of infectious waste. He comes across a technique that involves blending the waste with cement and other substances prior to its disposal. This method is best referred to as?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Inertization

Explanation:

  • • Inertization- mixing waste with cement and other substances before disposal, to minimize the risk of toxic substances contained in the waste migrating into the surface water or groundwater .
  • • Inertization-
  • • cement
  • • other substances
  • • minimize
  • • risk
  • • contained
  • • waste migrating
  • • surface water
  • • groundwater
  • • Inertization is especially suitable for pharmaceuticals and for incineration ashes with high metal content .
  • • Inertization
  • • pharmaceuticals
  • • incineration ashes
  • • high metal content
  • • A typical composition of the mixture is - 65% pharmaceutical waste , 15% lime, 15% cement, 5% water.
  • • composition
  • • 65% pharmaceutical waste
  • • 15% lime, 15% cement, 5% water.
  • • CEMENT IN BMW MANAGEMENT
  • • CEMENT IN BMW MANAGEMENT
  • • Encapsulation : Filling containers with waste, adding an immobilizing material ( plastic foam/ bituminous sand/cement mortar/clay material ) and sealing containers . The primary aim is to physically contain waste to prevent the migration of contaminants.
  • • Encapsulation
  • • containers
  • • waste,
  • • immobilizing material
  • • plastic foam/ bituminous sand/cement mortar/clay material
  • • sealing containers
  • • physically contain waste to
  • • prevent the migration of contaminants.
  • • Inertization: Mixing biomedical waste with cement and other substances ( lime ) before disposal . The primary aim is to render the waste chemically inactive or stable.
  • • Inertization:
  • • biomedical waste
  • • cement
  • • lime
  • • before disposal
  • • render
  • • waste
  • • chemically inactive or stable.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Inertization

  • ➤ before disposal

  • ➤ pharmaceuticals
  • ➤ for incineration ashes
  • ➤ high metal content

questions.text: A young and innovative healthcare administrator in Pune, is spearheading an initiative to revamp the hospital's waste management system. She learns about the Inertization process as an effective method for treating specific biomedical wastes. Before implementing this, she wants to ensure that her team uses the correct proportions of components in the process. What percentage of the mixture for the Inertization process should be made up of cement and water?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 15% and 5%

Explanation:

  • • A typical composition of the mixture is - 65% pharmaceutical waste, 15% lime, 15% cement, 5% water . A homogeneous mass is formed , and cubes or pellets are produced on site and then transported to suitable storage sites.

questions.text: Mrs. Rajkumari, an Auxiliary Nurse Midwife (ANM) working at a Tribal Sub Health Center in Chhattisgarh, has successfully assisted in a delivery. The mother, belonging to the local tribal community, and her newborn are both stable and in good health. Given the remote location of the Sub Health Center and the lack of access to standard Biomedical Waste Management procedures, how should Mrs. Rajkumari dispose of the placenta?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Deep burial

Explanation:

  • • Disposal by deep burial is permitted ONLY in rural or remote areas where there is no access to common bio-medical waste treatment facilities . This will be carried out with prior approval from the prescribed authority.
  • • Disposal
  • • deep burial
  • • ONLY in rural or remote areas
  • • no access
  • • bio-medical waste treatment facilities
  • • Deep burial is done for Human anatomical waste, Animal anatomical waste, and Soiled waste (ONLY In the absence of facilities like Autoclaving/Micro-waving/Hydroclaving followed by Shredding/Mutilation ).
  • • Deep burial
  • • Human anatomical waste, Animal anatomical waste,
  • • Soiled waste
  • • absence
  • • Autoclaving/Micro-waving/Hydroclaving
  • • Shredding/Mutilation
  • • Standards for Deep Burial
  • • Standards for Deep Burial
  • • Pit/Trench >2 meters deep , half filled with waste , then covered with lime within 50 cm of the surface, before filling the rest of the pit with soil. When wastes are added to the pit , a layer of 10 cm of soil shall be added to cover the wastes.
  • • Pit/Trench >2 meters deep , half filled with waste , then covered with lime within 50 cm of the surface, before filling the rest of the pit with soil.
  • • Pit/Trench >2 meters deep
  • • half filled
  • • waste
  • • lime
  • • 50 cm

  • • wastes
  • • added
  • • pit

  • • cover
  • • wastes.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Deep burial is the treatment and disposal option for Yellow bag/ category - Human & animal anatomical waste and soiled waste .
  • ➤ Deep burial

questions.text: As a healthcare facility manager, you are assessing various waste disposal methods, including chemical disinfection. This method involves using chemicals to neutralize potentially harmful biological agents in waste. However, not all types of waste are suitable for chemical disinfection. Based on your knowledge of waste types and appropriate disposal methods, which of the following types of waste is least suited for chemical disinfection?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Placenta

Explanation:

  • • Chemical disinfection employs the use of specific chemical agents to reduce the microbial load of waste to a level where they don't pose a health risk. While it's effective for many waste types like sharps, blood-soaked materials, hospital sewage and microbial specimens , it isn't suitable for large solid wastes like human anatomical waste.
  • • Chemical disinfection
  • • specific
  • • chemical agents
  • • reduce
  • • microbial load
  • • don't pose
  • • health risk.
  • • effective
  • • sharps, blood-soaked materials,
  • • hospital sewage
  • • microbial specimens
  • • isn't
  • • large solid
  • • human anatomical waste.
  • • Standards for Efficacy of Chemical Disinfection as per NEW Standards for BMW Treatment in India are - ≥ 4 Log10 reduction or greater for Bacillus Subtilis
  • • Standards
  • • Efficacy
  • • ≥ 4 Log10 reduction
  • • Bacillus Subtilis
  • • Examples of Chemical disinfectants : Bleaching powder , Chlorine solution , High test hypochlorite (HTH), Chlorine (Halozone) tablets , Iodine, Potassium permanganate.
  • • : Bleaching powder
  • • Chlorine solution
  • • High test hypochlorite (HTH),
  • • Chlorine (Halozone) tablets
  • • Iodine, Potassium permanganate.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Chemical disinfection is a widely used method for treating certain types of medical waste in healthcare facilities . It involves the application of chemical agents that are capable of destroying harmful microorganisms , making the waste safe for disposal or further handling . While this method is effective for various types of waste (Discarded linen, mattresses, beddings contaminated with blood or body fluid ), it is not the best suited for all. Specifically, placenta is not ideally suited for chemical disinfection .
  • • Chemical disinfection
  • • widely used
  • • medical waste
  • • healthcare facilities
  • • chemical agents
  • • destroying harmful microorganisms
  • • waste safe
  • • disposal or further handling
  • • method
  • • effective
  • • types of waste
  • • blood
  • • body fluid
  • • not
  • • placenta
  • • not
  • • chemical disinfection
  • • Reference: Park 26 th ed pg. 885

questions.text: Dr. Shruti, a young physician, joins a new hospital in Tamil Nadu. On her first day, she attended a mandatory orientation session about the hospital's protocols. There are specific rules and regulations in India that dictate how biomedical waste should be managed. Who provided the Biomedical Waste Management and Handling Rules?

options.label: A
options.text: Ministry of Health and Family welfare

options.label: B
options.text: Ministry of environment and forests and climate change.

questions.correct_answer: B. Ministry of environment and forests and climate change.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Ministry of environment and forests and climate change

  • • Radioactive wastes, Hazardous chemicals
  • • Municipal solid wastes
  • • Lead acid batteries, Hazardous wastes
  • • e-Waste
  • • Hazardous micro-organisms
  • • Genetically engineered microorganisms.
  • • BMW - emblem

questions.text: Mr. X, a 54-year-old man from Punjab, recently underwent colostomy surgery at a tertiary care hospital in Amritsar. Before the surgery, he was catheterized to ensure proper urinary drainage. On the 5th postoperative day, as he showed signs of recovery, the medical team decided to remove his urinary catheter. The nursing staff, while adhering to the Biomedical Waste Management protocols, planned to discard the used urine bag. In which colored container should they discard the urine bag as per the standard guidelines?

What should be the appropriate color of the container?

Ans. B. Yellow

questions.text: In the midst of a busy day at a large tertiary hospital in Uttar Pradesh, the nurse supervisor, Mrs. Gupta, is preparing a checklist for waste management training for new nurses. While listing down the different types of biomedical waste and their appropriate methods of disposal, she recalls that there's a specific type of waste that is typically NOT autoclaved before final disposal. Which of the following types of waste is Mrs. Gupta thinking about?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Cytotoxic drugs.

Explanation:

  • • Expired cytotoxic drugs and items contaminated with cytotoxic drugs to be returned to the manufacturer or supplier for incineration at temperature > 1200° C or to a common bio-medical waste treatment facility or hazardous waste treatment, storage and disposal facility for incineration at > 1200° C or Encapsulation or Plasma Pyrolysis at > 1200°C.
  • • Expired cytotoxic drugs
  • • items
  • • cytotoxic drugs
  • • returned

  • • bio-medical waste
  • • waste treatment, storage
  • • disposal facility
  • • > 1200° C
  • • Encapsulation or Plasma
  • • > 1200°C.
  • • All other discarded medicines shall be either sent back to the manufacturer or disposed of by incineration.
  • • discarded medicines
  • • either sent back
  • • manufacturer or disposed
  • • incineration.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Cytotoxic drugs , which are hazardous and used in treatments like chemotherapy , are not suitable for autoclaving due to their chemical properties. Instead, they require alternative disposal methods , such as high-temperature incineration , to ensure safety and environmental protection .
  • • Cytotoxic drugs
  • • chemotherapy

questions.text: A symbol is displayed during a training session for medical staff. The staff are asked to identify the symbol. Which of the following does the displayed symbol denote?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Biohazard

Explanation:

  • • THE BIOHAZARD SYMBOL:
  • • THE BIOHAZARD SYMBOL:
  • • An image that warns people of possible exposure to biological substances that are harmful to living organisms . These biohazards can be viruses, toxins or medical waste . Symbol was created by Charles Baldwin in 1966.

questions.text: In a medical facility, ensuring the efficacy of sterilization equipment like autoclaves is crucial for maintaining a sterile environment. To verify that an autoclave is functioning effectively, a biological indicator is used. What is the biological indicator commonly employed to test the efficacy of an autoclave?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Bacillus stearothermophillus

Explanation:

  • • Bacillus stearothermophillus is a widely recognized biological indicator for testing the efficacy of autoclaves . This thermophilic bacterium produces highly resistant spores , which can survive at high temperatures . The ability of an autoclave to effectively sterilize is demonstrated by its capacity to destroy these spores . If Bacillus stearothermophillus spores are killed during the autoclave process , it is a reliable indicator that the autoclave is functioning properly and achieving the necessary conditions for sterilization . This makes it a standard biological indicator for monitoring autoclave performance in healthcare settings.

  • • Autoclaving
  • • Bio-Medical Waste:
  • • Biological indicator: Geobacillus stearothermophilus (GBS) spores using vials or spore Strips ; with at least 1 × 10 6 spores.
